Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> ```
Emulating the embedded node
In binary releases, SilentDragon will use node binaries in the current directory to sync a node from scratch. It does not attempt to download them, it bundles them. To simulate this from a developer setup, you can symlink these four files in your Git repo:

    ln -s ../hush3/src/hushd
    ln -s ../hush3/src/hush-cli
    ln -s ../hush3/src/komodod
    ln -s ../hush3/src/komodo-cli
The above assumes silentdragon and hush3 git repos are in the same directory. File names on Windows will need to be tweaked.
```

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> from https://github.com/MyHush/SilentDragon#emulating-the-embedded-node

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the "hushd" tab will give you more details while syncing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> this also makes me wonder, if I could add a feature that tries to help people decide "Am I on a fork?"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it could contact the explorer, and compare 2 blocks and make sure they are the same hash, if not => you are probably on a fork

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <iceyballz> That would be great, just compare sync height to explorer height

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> well, heights could be different from propagation time and network delay

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <iceyballz> Ah good point

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> but a past block hash should never be different, if it's been notarized

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> so we look back at a notarized block and verify the blockhash is the same, otherwise either the explorer or current node is on a fork

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <iceyballz> So you would need to check several items then: current height when at 100%, comparative block hash, etc.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> might be a useful warning to give

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @iceyballz nope

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <iceyballz> Because if the forked chain stopped mining, it's height would not increment??

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the only thing to look at is "a past notarized blockhash"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <iceyballz> Or is it different with dPOW

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> which cannot change, via consensus rules

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> forked chains often do not have any notarizations, as well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <iceyballz> Ah ok

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <iceyballz> Still getting up to speed with Komodo's protocol

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> DPoW basically brings blockhash data from HUSH => KMD => BTC

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and then all HUSH nodes read that data, and enforce rules via consensus

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> so the algo would be "find the last notarized block hash + height, and then verify the same block height has the same blockhash on the explorer. If not, either the explorer or current node is on a fork"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @iceyballz this might catch you up: https://github.com/leto/mastering_komodo_dpow/blob/master/mastering_komodo_dpow.md

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that is written from the perspective of a dev adding DPoW to a new coin and gives a nice overview
